official-title.#text: To improve science, technology, engineering, and mathematics education, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Education and the Workforce

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

It is the purpose of this section to encourage individuals educated in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics to enter and continue in the teaching profession, with the goal of attracting 10,000 of America’s brightest students to the teaching profession over the next 5 years.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall award scholarships, on a competitive basis and in accordance with this part, to students who are enrolled in studies leading to bachelor’s degrees, with concurrent certification as kindergarten, elementary, and secondary school teachers, in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, and who have agreed to perform qualified service.

text.#text: Scholarships shall be awarded for only one academic year of study at a time, and shall be renewable on an annual basis for the established length of the recipient’s academic program, not to exceed 6 academic years. The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to complete no less than 5 academic years of qualified service during a 7-year period, to begin no later than 12 months following the completion of a bachelor’s degree in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics.

term.#tail: means full-time employment at a public or private kindergarten, elementary school, or secondary school as a teacher of a course in a science, technology, engineering, or mathematics field.

The maximum award any student may receive under this section for an academic year shall be the student’s cost of attendance minus any grant aid such student receives from sources other than this section.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Title II of the Higher Education Act of 1965

internal-xref.#tail: of this section, the following new part:

header.#text: Institutional grants for Integrated Degree Programs

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is authorized to award grants to institutions of higher education, on a competitive basis, in order to pay for the Federal share of the cost of projects to establish, strengthen, and operate 4-year undergraduate degree programs through which students may concurrently—

text.#text: The
earn a bachelor’s degree in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics; and
be certified to teach kindergarten, elementary, or secondary school.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may award grants to no more than 50 institutions of higher education each fiscal year, and a grant to an institution for a fiscal year shall not exceed $1,000,000. Grants shall be awarded for only one fiscal year at a time, and shall be renewable on an annual basis for up to 5 years.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall set criteria to evaluate the applications for grants under this part and the projects proposed to establish, strengthen, and operate 4-year integrated undergraduate degree programs.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall make grants under this part in such manner as to achieve an equitable distribution of the grant funds throughout the United States, considering geographic distribution, rural and urban areas, and range and type of institutions.

text.#text: To the extent practicable and consistent with the criteria under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the
may require. Such application shall include the following:

text.#text: In order to receive a grant under this part, an institution of higher education shall submit an application to the
A description of the proposed project.
A demonstration of—
the commitment, including the financial commitment, of the institution for the proposed project; and
the active support of the leadership of the institution for the proposed project.
A description of how the proposed project will be continued after Federal funds are no longer awarded under this part for the project.
A plan for the evaluation of the project, which shall include benchmarks to monitor progress toward specific project objectives.

Each institution of higher education receiving a grant under this part shall provide, from non-Federal sources, an amount equal to the amount of the grant (in cash or in kind) to carry out the project supported by the grant.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}fund.#text: $50,000,000 for each of the fiscal years 2014 through 2019
